titleStmt.title: The Speech of the Provost of T──y Coll──ge
To His Royall Highness George

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Illustrious Prince We're come before You,
Who more than in Our Founder's GloryTo be by You Protected;
Deign to Descend and Give us Laws,
For We are Converts to Your Cause,From this day well Affected.2
The Noble View of Your high Merits
Has Charm'd Our Thoughts, and fir'd Our SpiritsWith Zeal so warm and Hearty;
That we resolv'd to be devoted,
Att least untill We be promoted,By Your Just Pow'r and Party.3
Urg'd by a passionate desire,
Of being Rais'd a little higher,From a Lazy Cloister'd Life,
We cannot Flatter You nor Fawn
But fain wou'd honour'd be with LawnAnd settled by a Wife.4
For this We have before resorted
Paid Levees punctually, and Courted,Our Charge att home long Quitting
But now We're come just in ye Nick
Upon a Vacant Bishoprick;This Bait can't fail of hitting.5
Thus Sṛ, You see how much Affection,
Not Intrest sways in this Election,But sense of Loyall Duty;
For You surpass all Princes far,
As Glow-Worms do Exceed a Star,In Goodness, Witt, and Beauty.6
To You our Irish Commons owe
That Wisdom which their Actions show,Their Principles from Ours springs;
Taught e'er the Deel himself could dream on't,
That of Their Illustrious House a stem on't,Shou'd Rise the Best of Kings.7
The Glad Presages with our Eyes
Behold a King, Chaste, Vigilant and Wise,In Forreign Fields Victorious
Who in his Youth The Turks Attacks
And them still to Turn their Backs,Was ever King so Glorious?8
Since Ormond's like a Traytor Gone,
We scorn to do what some have done,For Learning much more famous;
Fools may pursue their adverse Fate,
And stick to the Unfortunate,We Laugh while They Condemn us.9
For being of that Gen'rous Mind,
To Success We are still inclin'd,And Quitt the suffring side:
If On our Friends Cross Planetts Frown
We joyn the Crye and Hunt them down,And sail with Wind and Tide.10
Hence 'twas this Choice we long delay'd,
Till our Rash Foes the Rebells Fled,Whilst Fortune held the scale;
But they're driv'n like Mist before You,
Our Riseing Sun, We Now Adore You,Because You now prevail.11
Descend then from Your Lofty seat,
Behold th'Attending Muses WaiteWith us to sing Your Praises;
Calliope now strings up her Lyre,
And Cloe Phoebus do's inspire,The Theam their Fancy raises.12
If then Our Nursery You will Nourish,
We and Our Muses too will flourish,Encourag'd by Yṛ Favour;
We'll Doctrines teach the Times to serve,
And more Five Thousand Pounds deserve,By Future Good Behaviour.13
Now take Our Harp into Your hand,
The joyfull strings att Your Command,In dolefull sounds no more shall mourn;
We with sincerity of Heart,
To all Your Tunes shall bear a Part,Unless We see the Tables Turn.14
If so Great Sṛ, You will Excuse us,
For We and Our Attending MusesMay live to Change Our strain;
And Turn with merry hearts our Tune
Upon some happy Tenth of June,To the King Enjoys his own again.X99A002D
